w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach more chores by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum, I need to clean ____, What room is not clean?
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for chores
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum
This slide will always be the Naativ-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about more chores!”
Chant the song on the screen with your teacher
Chant the poem above in a sing-song way. Encourage the child to join in as much as possible.
Circle the four pictures of the children cleaning one at a time and repeat the words,
Look at the different kinds of chores your teacher points out.
and say it. Have the child repeat. Circle the different kinds of chores the child is doing in the pictures.
Review these chores. Write the missing verb on the line.
Circle the first picture. Start reading the phrase and encourage the child to finish. Repeat with all three pictures.
Review these chores by writing the missing word in the phrases.

Circle the first picture and underline the phrase beside it. Read the partial phrase. Encourage the child to say the missing word. Start to write the word on the line and encourage the child to finish.
and circle the cleaning tools. Have the child repeat.
See what cleaning products students know.
I need to clean my bedroom.
at the same time. Clear the screen. Ask the child to circle the room. Have the child say,
Circle what is NOT clean, shake your head, “no,” and say,
Encourage the child to find things that are not clean.
I need to put my clothes away
Underline the bold phrase and say,
I need to put my clothes away
with an action of pretending to put clothes away. Have the child repeat.
Spell it and have the child repeat.
I need to clean the bathroom.
at the same time. Clear the screen. Ask the child to circle the bathroom. Have the child say,
Circle what is NOT clean, shake your head, “no,” and say,
Encourage the child to find things that are not clean.
I need to clean the sink
Underline the bold phrase and say,
I need to clean the sink
with an action of pretending to wash a sink. Have the child repeat.
Spell it and have the child repeat.
This is the bathroom, This is the bedroom
Tell what you can clean in each room
Circle the first picture and say,
Encourage and prompt the child to answer in a complete sentence,
Ask the child, “What can you clean in the bathroom?” Encourage the child to say,
I need to clean the sink.
I need to clean the kitchen.
at the same time. Clear the screen. Ask the child to circle the kitchen. Have the child say,
Circle what is NOT clean, shake your head, “no,” and say,
Encourage the child to find things that are not clean.
I need to wash the dishes
Underline the bold phrase and say,
I need to wash the dishes
with an action of pretending to wash a plate. Have the child repeat.
Spell it and have the child repeat.
I need to clean the living room.
at the same time. Clear the screen. Ask the child to circle the living room. Have the child say,
Circle what is NOT clean, shake your head, “no,” and say,
Encourage the child to find things that are not clean.
Underline the bold phrase and say,
I need to wash the dishes
with an action of pretending to wash a plate. Have the child repeat.
Spell it and have the child repeat.
Tell what room is not clean
Ask the child, “What room is NOT clean? Encourage the child to say,
The living room is not clean, The kitchen is not clean, The bedroom is not clean.
Tell what needs to be cleaned in each room (
I need to vacuum, I need to put clothes away, I need to do dishes)
Circle the dirty dishes in the kitchen. Ask the child,
What do you need to clean?
I need to wash the dishes.
Repeat with the living room and bedroom.
Review chores from the beginning of the lesson (folding clothes, making the bed, folding towels, setting the table, picking up toys, sweeping the floor). Find the chores in the picture.
Review chores from the beginning of the lesson (folding clothes, making the bed, folding towels, setting the table, pick up toys, sweep the floor).
Draw a line from the picture to the key word
I need to vacuum, I need to wash the dishes, I need to put away the clothes, I need to clean the sink)
Model drawing a line from the girl putting away her clothes to the words,
I need to put my clothes away.
Have the child finish the other three pictures and phrases the same way.
Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide
Students should have a blank slide to draw a picture of
clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum
clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum)
Teacher will prompt student to draw a picture to represent
clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum
through pictures. One prompt at a time.
Teacher will write words from the lesson (
clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum)
Word Wall Vocabulary Builder Activity – Slide 22
Students will read and spell their new words:
clean, chores, clothes, sink, dishes, vacuum
Teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
